cards.title: Fake Online Shopping Site
cards.message: You find an online retailer selling the exact laptop you want at 70% off. The website looks professional with good reviews, but the price is significantly lower than anywhere else.

options.text: Make the purchase immediately to get the amazing deal
options.feedback: Red flag! Clone websites are designed to look legitimate. Check domain spelling, contact retailers through official sites, and verify reviews.

options.text: Search the retailer's name and verify it's their official website
options.feedback: Smart! Verify by going to the official website directly or calling the company. Prices too good to be true usually are.

options.text: Check the reviews and proceed if they're positive
options.feedback: Fake reviews are easy to create. Verify the website domain and contact the company directly instead.

cards.title: Phishing Email at Home
cards.message: You receive an email saying your bank account has suspicious activity. It asks you to click a link to verify your identity immediately or your account will be locked.

options.text: Click the link immediately to prevent lockout
options.feedback: Phishing attempt! Banks never ask you to verify via email links. Go directly to your bank's official website or call them.

options.text: Go directly to your bank's website or call their customer service number
options.feedback: Perfect! Verify through official channels only. Real banks never threaten account lockout via email.

options.text: Reply to ask for more information first
options.feedback: Never reply to suspicious emails. This confirms your email is active. Delete it and contact your bank directly.

cards.title: Social Media Account Takeover
cards.message: You notice a friend's social media account posted about cryptocurrency investments. This seems very unlike them. You also notice unusual login alerts in your own account.

options.text: Ignore it - social media isn't important
options.feedback: Account hijacking is serious! Change your password immediately using a secure device. Tell your friend to do the same.

options.text: Change your password immediately and warn your friend to secure their account
options.feedback: Excellent! Unusual activity means compromised accounts. Act immediately. Warn your friend and protect your own accounts.

options.text: Post a warning on the social media platform about the hijack
options.feedback: The attacker controls the account. Change your password first, then secure other accounts, then warn friends privately.

cards.title: Smart Home Device Password
cards.message: You set up a new smart doorbell camera for your front door. It asks you to set a password. You're tempted to use the default password or something simple since it's 'just for your home.'

options.text: Use the default password or a simple one for convenience
options.feedback: Major security risk! Weak passwords allow attackers to access your home camera and other connected devices. Use a strong, unique password.

options.text: Create a strong, unique password different from other devices
options.feedback: Perfect! Smart devices control access to your home. Strong passwords prevent surveillance and network compromise.

options.text: Use a password you've used for other home devices
options.feedback: If one device is compromised, all your home devices are at risk. Each device needs a unique strong password.

cards.title: Package Delivery Scam
cards.message: You receive a text message saying 'Package delivery failed. Click here to reschedule delivery.' You're expecting a delivery, but something feels off about the message.

options.text: Click the link to reschedule your delivery
options.feedback: Delivery scam! Check your official delivery account directly. Don't click unsolicited messages. Scammers steal payment info this way.

options.text: Check your official delivery account or contact the carrier directly
options.feedback: Smart! Verify through official channels. Legitimate carriers rarely use text links. These are common phishing tactics.

options.text: Ask a friend if they received a similar message
options.feedback: Good instinct but verify independently. Check your official account or call the carrier directly.

cards.title: Home Network Wi-Fi Security
cards.message: Your home Wi-Fi router is 5 years old. You've never changed the default password. Recently you've noticed unknown devices connecting to your network.

options.text: Leave it as-is - your home Wi-Fi is low-risk
options.feedback: High risk! Unknown devices mean compromised network. Change your router password immediately and update firmware.

options.text: Change the router password immediately and update the firmware
options.feedback: Excellent! Unknown devices are a major red flag. Secure your network immediately. Attackers can intercept all your data.

options.text: Check if the unknown devices are from family members
options.feedback: They might not be! Change your password first to stop the intrusion. Then investigate what connected.

cards.title: Card Details on Receipt
cards.message: After a shopping trip, you notice your receipt shows your full credit card number. You're keeping it in your wallet. A family member says you should dispose of it securely.

options.text: Keep the receipt in your wallet for warranty purposes
options.feedback: Security risk! Full card numbers on receipts can lead to fraud. Shred or destroy receipts with payment information.

options.text: Shred the receipt securely after confirming the purchase with your bank
options.feedback: Perfect! Never keep receipts with card numbers. Dumpster diving for receipts is a real fraud technique.

options.text: Store it in a safe place at home
options.feedback: Still risky! Receipts with card data should be destroyed, not stored. Shred them securely.

cards.title: Free Antivirus Download
cards.message: Your computer is running slowly. You see an ad for 'Free Antivirus - Download Now!' while browsing. It promises to remove viruses and improve performance.

options.text: Download and install the free antivirus immediately
options.feedback: Malware red flag! These ads often distribute malware. Use legitimate antivirus like Windows Defender or known providers.

options.text: Use Windows Defender (included) or purchase from reputable providers
options.feedback: Smart! Free antivirus ads are often malware. Use built-in Windows Defender or trusted paid alternatives.

options.text: Research the provider before downloading
options.feedback: Even with research, don't download from ads. Use Windows Defender or reputable antivirus providers instead.

cards.title: Social Media Personal Information
cards.message: You post frequently on social media - your daily activities, where you're traveling this week, and photos of your family members. Your profile is set to 'public.'

options.text: Continue posting as-is - sharing is normal on social media
options.feedback: Privacy and security risk! Criminals use this info for break-ins, identity theft, and targeting. Limit audience and reduce personal details.

options.text: Change to private/friends-only and be selective about personal information
options.feedback: Perfect! Control who sees your information. Never post real-time location, travel plans, or reveal when you're away.

options.text: Keep sharing but avoid mentioning when you're away
options.feedback: Better but incomplete! Change to private settings and be more selective about all personal information, not just location.

cards.title: Romance Scam
cards.message: You meet someone online who seems perfect. After weeks of chatting, they ask to transfer $2,000 to them 'for an emergency' and promise to pay you back.

options.text: Send the money to help someone in need
options.feedback: Romance scam! You'll never see this money or this person again. Never send money to online strangers, even with promises of repayment.

options.text: Politely decline and end contact if they persist
options.feedback: Correct! Real relationships don't involve sudden money requests. This is a classic romance scam tactic.

options.text: Ask for collateral or a reason for the emergency first
options.feedback: No legitimate reason justifies sending money to online strangers. Scammers have stories prepared for any objection.

cards.title: Unsolicited Tech Support Call
cards.message: Someone calls your home saying they're from Microsoft and detected a virus on your computer. They offer to fix it remotely for $99. You recognize nothing unusual with your computer.

options.text: Grant remote access and pay the fee
options.feedback: Tech support scam! Microsoft never calls unsolicited. Hang up. These scams steal data and install malware.

options.text: Hang up immediately. Microsoft never calls unsolicited about viruses
options.feedback: Perfect! This is a classic scam. Real companies don't cold-call about problems. Hang up and don't engage.

options.text: Ask them for a reference number to verify later
options.feedback: Scammers have scripted answers. Don't engage. Simply hang up. Real support won't call unsolicited.

cards.title: Password Written Down
cards.message: You have multiple passwords for your online accounts. You've written them down on a sticky note and stuck it to your monitor at home for easy reference.

options.text: Keep the sticky note for convenience
options.feedback: Major security risk! Anyone with access to your home can see them. Use a password manager instead.

options.text: Use a password manager app to securely store your passwords
options.feedback: Excellent! Password managers are secure and convenient. Never write passwords on paper or sticky notes.

options.text: Move the sticky note to a hidden place in your home
options.feedback: Still not secure enough. Use a password manager instead. Family, guests, or burglars could find written passwords.

cards.title: Lottery Win Scam
cards.message: You receive an email saying you've won a lottery you never entered. They claim you won $500,000 and need to pay a $1,000 'processing fee' to claim your prize.

options.text: Pay the processing fee to claim your prize
options.feedback: Scam! You never entered. Legitimate lotteries don't require payment to claim prizes. Never send money for 'processing fees.'

options.text: Delete the email. Legitimate lotteries don't ask for upfront fees
options.feedback: Perfect! Classic advance-fee fraud. Real lotteries deduct taxes from your winnings, never ask for fees upfront.

options.text: Research the lottery company before responding
options.feedback: There's nothing to research - you didn't enter! This is a scam. Delete it and don't engage.

cards.title: Malware Download
cards.message: You're looking for a popular movie online. You find a download site that promises the movie for free. After downloading, your computer starts showing ads everywhere.

options.text: Continue using the file - the ads will probably go away
options.feedback: Adware or malware infection! These aggressive ads usually hide worse malware. Scan immediately and consider professional help.

options.text: Run a full malware scan and remove the infected files
options.feedback: Correct action! Use reputable antivirus to scan. In future, use legitimate streaming services instead of downloads.

options.text: Just delete the movie file
options.feedback: The malware may have spread beyond that file. Run a full system scan to ensure complete removal.

cards.title: Data Broker Privacy
cards.message: You discover websites are selling your personal information - name, address, phone, email - for marketing purposes. This data likely came from a data breach you experienced.

options.text: Accept it as normal and do nothing
options.feedback: You have rights! Contact the data brokers to request removal. Also freeze your credit to prevent identity theft.

options.text: Contact the data brokers to request removal and consider a credit freeze
options.feedback: Smart! You can request removal from many data brokers. A credit freeze prevents criminals from opening accounts in your name.

options.text: Only protect your bank account - other data doesn't matter
options.feedback: Personal data enables many fraud types. Freeze your credit and remove it from data brokers where possible.

cards.title: Family Member Device Access
cards.message: Your teenager asks to borrow your laptop 'to do homework.' You leave it unlocked while they're using it and they could see your passwords, banking information, and personal files.

options.text: Let them use the laptop unattended - they're family
options.feedback: Risk! Even trusted family members might accidentally access sensitive data. Either supervise or create a separate user account.

options.text: Create a separate guest/child account or supervise their use
options.feedback: Perfect! Separate accounts protect sensitive data. This also prevents accidental changes to your system.

options.text: Just tell them not to look at sensitive files
options.feedback: Not enough! Accidental clicks happen. Create a separate account or supervise to prevent unauthorized access.

cards.title: Suspicious Software Update
cards.message: Your antivirus software shows a notification that your system has viruses and wants you to click 'Update Now!' to fix them immediately. This notification appeared suddenly.

options.text: Click 'Update Now!' immediately to fix the viruses
options.feedback: Fake notification! Scareware scam. Open your real antivirus manually to scan. Don't click popup buttons.

options.text: Close the popup and manually open your real antivirus software to scan
options.feedback: Excellent! Scareware uses fake warnings to trick you. Always open software manually, never click suspicious popups.

options.text: Click update but pay close attention to what's happening
options.feedback: Still risky! Close the popup immediately. Open your legitimate antivirus manually to perform a real scan.

cards.title: Online Banking Security
cards.message: You're banking online from your home computer. Your browser shows a 'Not Secure' warning but the site looks like your bank's interface. You proceed anyway because you're in a hurry.

options.text: Proceed with banking - the interface is correct
options.feedback: Security risk! 'Not Secure' warnings mean no encryption. This could be a fake site. Close and type the bank's URL directly.

options.text: Close the site immediately and navigate to your bank's official URL
options.feedback: Perfect! HTTPS (secure) is essential for banking. Never ignore security warnings. Type the URL directly.

options.text: Use your bank's mobile app instead to bypass the warning
options.feedback: Better choice but first verify - this might still be a fake site. Download the app from official stores only.

cards.title: Public Computer Usage
cards.message: You're at a library and need to check your email urgently. You log into your email on a public computer and access your account.

options.text: Log in and check your email as needed
options.feedback: High risk! Public computers can have malware or keyloggers. Your credentials could be stolen. Wait or use your phone instead.

options.text: Use your phone's mobile data instead of the public computer
options.feedback: Perfect! Mobile data is encrypted and private. Avoid sensitive activities on public computers.

options.text: Use a public computer but change your password immediately after
options.feedback: Too risky! Credentials could be stolen before you change the password. Use your phone instead.
